_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Mission Bell Winery is located at 12667 Road 24, Madera, California and is operated by Canandaigua Wine which is owned by Constellation Brands, Inc. It is designed as a wine grape processing and wine production facility. All process and operations conducted at the facility are integral parts of the winemaking and distribution.

Canandaigua Wine maintains a commitment to worker and public safety as evidenced by the resources invested in accident prevention and in the consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the Mission Bell Winery.  Canandaigua Wine maintains a proactive stance, as a labor intensive agricultural based industry, Canandaigua Wine is dedicated to the protection of natural and human resources.

COVERED PROCESSES

1.550 REFRIGERATION SYSTEM

The Refrigeration system is a Risk Management Program 3 (RMP). This process is a centralized ammonia compression refrigeration system consisting of four (4) 700 hp screw compressors, high pressure receiver, and one (1) low pressure liquid ammonia recirculation system. There are fourteen (14) shell & tube heat exchangers used for direct cooling of wine. The low pressure recirculator serves the cooling jackets on fourteen (14) storage and fermenting tanks.

2.NEUTRALIZATION AND ION EXCHANGE STORAGE SYSTEM

The Neutralization and Ion Exchange Storage system is a RMP Program 3. Both the Neutralization and Ion Exchange systems utilize the anhydrous ammonia stored in a 11,897 gallon ASME Code Pressure Vessel. The Neutralization system uses anhydrous ammonia to neutralize sulfur dioxide emissions in an evaporative cooling water tower.  The evaporative cooling water tower concentrates juice for processing. The cooling tower water is continuously monitored by an in line pH analyzer.  This analyzer signals a control valve that meters an appropriate amount of ammonia into the water to correct the pH. The Ion Exchange system neutralizes the effect of sulfuric acid in the cation/anion d

emineralization beds.  The cation/anion demineralization system is used to purify water utilized within the plant operations.  

3.SULFUR DIOXIDE SYSTEM

The Sulfur Dioxide system is a RMP program 3. This process is the simple transfer of liquid anhydrous sulfur dioxide from a one-ton cylinder into smaller gauging cylinders. This process uses gravity assisted by inert gas counterpressure to provide the motive force. The smaller cylinders are used for injecting and circulating sulfur dioxide into the wine to inhibit, and stop the fermentation process.


4.RED WINE REFRIGERATION SYSTEM

The Refrigeration Expansion system is a RMP program 3. This process is a centralized ammonia compression refrigeration system consisting of one (1) 450 hp FES rotary screw compressors, and one (1) low pressure liquid ammonia recirculation systems. There are eight (8) shell & tube heat exchangers used for direct cooling of wine. The low pressure recirculator serves the cooling jackets on eight (8) storage and fermenting tanks.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN/PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT

In addition to being regulated by 40 CFR Part 68 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and 19 CCR 2735 California Accidental Release Prevention Program, the Mission Bell Winery is regulated by Title 8 CCR 5189 Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials (PSM).  A RMP/PSM program has been implemented at the Mission Bell Winery.

The Mission Bell Winery RMP/PSM Prevention Program has multiple elements to ensure the safety of employees and the public.  The main elements of the program are discussed in the following paragraphs.

Employee Participation includes involvement in the process hazard analysis, development and review of operating procedures, process safety information, and mechanical integrity inspections.  

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been conducted on the existing systems. The PHA methodologies used are What If/Checklists based on the Uniform Mechanical Code, ANSI/IIAR 2 1999, IIAR Bulletin 110, Co

mpressed Gas Association, and ANSI K61.1.  The PHA is revalidated every 5 years.

Annual certification is performed for the process safety information and operating procedures.  Training on operating procedures and mechanical integrity is provided to affected employees.  All employees are trained in Hazard Communication and the Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The PSM/RMP program also has procedures for Hot Work, Contractors, Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review.

Annual inspections are conducted for Storm Water Pollution Prevention compliance, Hazardous Materials Inventory Reporting, and Toxic Chemical Release Inventory Reporting requirements. All programs and policies are designed for compliance with applicable environmental and safety regulations including Title 8 CCR General Industry Safety Orders. Some of the additional programs and policies that are currently in place:

?Injury and Illness Prevention Program
?Respiratory Protection
?Hazard Communication
?Confined Space Entry
?Control of Hazardous Energy
?Accident Investigation
?Storm Water Pollution Prevention
?Hazardous Materials Management Plan
?Toxic Chemical Release Program
?ISO 9000 Skills Based Matrix



Safety meetings are held regularly by Department Managers and all employees are provided with initial training and annual refresher training in all necessary safety programs.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

No reportable accidents have occurred within the last five years at Mission Bell Winery.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

It is the goal of Canandaigua Wine to be self-sufficient in responding to the control and containment of hazardous materials or other emergencies. Canandaigua recognizes that inadequately trained and equipped personnel can result in an injury. For this reason the emergency response program will utilize a combination of response strategies. On-site personnel are trained first in awareness and self-protection, and then in specific control and containment procedures. Reporting and

communications with emergency response agencies is entailed in the program. An ongoing commitment to joint participation exercises with local emergency responders is a key element of the program.

For emergency releases of hazardous materials, employees have been instructed to evacuate the area and notify their supervisor. The supervisor will assess the situation, and notify the local fire department to respond, if warranted. Employees are notified to evacuate by (1) winery siren, (2) verbal instructions, and/or (3) two-way radio communication.

The Winery Manager is responsible to make the proper notifications in case of an emergency release. Immediate verbal notifications and follow-up notice reporting for a hazardous release is detailed in the emergency response program.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Upgrades in technology, automated process controls, new standards and methods are reviewed and considered for implementation as part of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). In addition to the PHA, planned changes to improve safety are evaluated as a result of RMP/PSM compliance audits. The Mission Bell Winery maintains certification in ISO 9000. In addition, Mission Bell Winery is participating in the Cal OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).
